title: 109_hr4535
content: The "Congressional Integrity and Pension Forfeiture Act of 2005" states that Members of Congress who breach the public trust and are convicted of a felony should forfeit their retirement benefits, as taxpayers should not bear the cost. The "Congressional Integrity and Pension Forfeiture Act of 2005" mandates that individuals finally convicted of specific offenses while serving as Members of Congress will not have their service counted for retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. They will be entitled to receive their lump-sum credit attributable to the disqualified service. The "Congressional Integrity and Pension Forfeiture Act of 2005" stipulates that individuals convicted of certain offenses related to their service as Members of Congress after the enactment of the Act will forfeit their retirement benefits under the Civil Service Retirement System. The specified offenses include bribery, compensation, practice in federal courts, restrictions on former officials, acting as agents of foreign principals, conspiracy to defraud the Government, and making false claims. The curr_chunk lists various offenses under title 18 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including fraud, conspiracy, influencing officers, interference with commerce, and tax evasion. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 outlines offenses such as tax evasion, perjury, and subornation of perjury. Individuals convicted of these offenses are ineligible to participate in the retirement system while serving as a Member. The Office will establish regulations to implement these rules, including limiting interest on lump-sum payments. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 prohibits individuals convicted of offenses like tax evasion from participating in the retirement system while serving as a Member. The Executive Director will establish regulations for the Thrift Savings Plan, including the return of vested amounts attributable to service as a Member. This subsection does not limit authorities to deny benefits authorized by statute. The term 'Member' is defined as per section 2106, not section 8331(2). The amendment to the Federal Employees' Retirement System prohibits individuals convicted of certain offenses from having their service counted for retirement benefits. Offenses committed while serving as a Member are not considered for benefits, and the individual is entitled to their lump-sum credit. The amendment to the Federal Employees' Retirement System prohibits convicted individuals from receiving retirement benefits for offenses related to their service as a Member. Convicted individuals are not eligible for the retirement system while serving as a Member, and regulations will be prescribed to enforce this provision. Regulations will require the return of vested amounts related to service as a Member. No restrictions on denying benefits under other laws. The term 'Member' is defined as per section 2106.
